description: Etobicoke is a relaxed area along the Humber River. It's saturated with green spaces and conservatories, making it a premier destination for outdoor sports, hiking, and nature walks. Its abundance of parkland and lakes makes it a typical spot for fishing, picnicking, and camping out, especially in warmer months. The peaceful area is also enjoyed by families, who appreciate its boardwalks and sports facilities. Locals enjoy the variety of golfing and country club opportunities, which also provide lessons for golfers of any skill level.

reviews.title: Open on holidays
text: After lunch at Pho Ngoc Yen, our group travelled the short distance to Centennial Park Conservatory & Greenhouse in a two-car convoy. We arrived around 1:20pm and conveniently found 2 adjacent empty parking spots in the parking lot to the left of the conservatory. Centennial Park is a popular picnic spot so we were lucky we got to park easily in the early afternoon of a holiday (Victoria Day). Parking is free of charge.

Admission to Centennial Park Conservatory is free of charge as well. Double entrance is at the front of the glass-enclosed greenhouse, behind  the flagpole. The conservatory is open every day, including holidays, from 10am to 5pm. A sign says last entry is at 4:45pm. Separate male and female multi-stall washrooms are located in the premises. There is even a water bottle refill station and drinking fountain.

We spent 40 mins exploring the small conservatory looking at assorted tropical plants, trees, flowers and succulents. Not every plant on display is labelled. One of the plants we found interesting had curly green and yellow leaves which I’m sure I’ve never seen before. We also saw a Philippine lemon tree with massive, overripe calamansi fruit hanging on the branches. A staffer was busy working at one end of the greenhouse.
Since it is warm inside, it is best to wear light clothing. Do bring a hat as the glass roof lets in sunlight in abundance. Plenty of bench seating for short stops or photo ops.

We spent the rest of the afternoon at the wooden pergola outside the conservatory where a huge tree provided welcome shade. Frogs living in the small pond regularly chimed in while our group conversed nonstop.

reviews.title: consistently well maintained and Beautiful Displays
text: This basically non profit lovely greenhouse is a must see if you are in the etobicoke area. Located at the south end of Centennial park close to west Toronto. once the quarantine is lifted try to pop in and see the various seasonal displays and also a cactus house. You can take photos and there is an option to make a small donation. Free parking and washrooms.

reviews.title: Great spot for anyone who is a lover of plants & florals.
text: Easy to get to location, plenty of free parking this is a wonderfully manicured greenhouse for anyone who would appreciate a variety of florals, plants and cacti. The donation box is worth contributing to to maintain it's pedigree. There is a park next door if you had little ones who might appreciate some playtime.

reviews.title: Beautiful flowers!
text: A great place to visit anytime as the flowers and plants are indoor. Beautiful variety of plants and flowers (lots of stunning hydrangeas during my visit). They also had some unique plants and cactus. Grounds surrounding the greenhouse were also really nice.No charge for admission and plenty of parking.

reviews.title: Beautiful and varied foliage!
text: The flowers and plants transport you into heaven! You have every colour of hydrangea...a feast for the eyes! Then you have an entire section of cacti and orchids and other tropical plants. Amazing how well they are cared for! And as a bonus, there's free parking and entry. You can drop a donation as you leave. Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: BEAUTIFUL AS USUAL
text: I took my 93 yr old mother to see the flowers on Easter Sunday.  Boy, was it crowded.  Everybody had the same idea.  Flowers were lovely and the fragrance was great.

reviews.title: An oasis after the winter blues
text: Such a delight to enter this peaceful space and see the beauty of so any different species of plants. Lots of flowering cacti, and some usual hydrangea plants I've never seen before. Wish the plants would have been better marked, but it's still a great place to visit for a short visit. No charge for parking, and donations only.

reviews.title: Nice Way to Beat the Winter Blues
text: Wish I’d known about this place sooner! When you open the door, you are immediately greeted by the smell of flowers, and then enter into a tropical greenhouse. There are two other greenhouses off this main one with different types of plants. What a beautiful way to spend some time!

reviews.title: Great retreat from the winter
text: Just a minute through the naturally scented doors and you already feel rejuvenated.  It's a treasure of an oasis especially during winter and harsh months.  The tropical flair provides a great relaxation venue and natural therapy for anyone needed a nice outdoor experience.  Birds, fish and fauna galore.  Thank you for the many days of hard work and dedication to those individuals who are providing an excellent service.

reviews.title: Feel the warmth of summer in the cold of winter
text: ON a cold January day I went to see the flowers at this Greenhouse. One of the City of Toronto's hidden gems, it sits on the far west side of the city. Entry is free (though a small donation is appreciated) and there is lots of free parking.

Entering the greenhouse you are greeted with warm, fragrant air and a riot of bright colours. Quite a treat in the depths of winter! Classical music was quietly playing during my visit which adds to the sense of tranquility. The greenhouse offers a variety of species and lots of opportunity for photos. There is also a pond complete with fish and a couple of turtles. Benches dotted throughout the area encourage you to sit and relax. Maybe read for a while :)

reviews.title: Worth a Visit, If You're Not Too Far Away
text: I was surprised to learn about the Centennial Park Conservatory as I was already familiar with the Allan Gardens Conservatory via advertising.

While walking up to the conservatory, I was admiring the cabbages in the outdoor garden when I realized something was moving. Initially I thought it was a duck but then realized it was a pheasant! A nice surprise. Inside the main building, we were greeted by a different bird, a cockatoo. He was quite entertaining!

The grounds were well maintained and the displays were quite creative in honour of the holiday season. I loved the poinsettia display arranged as a large fireplace. In the arid section, there were Christmas trees made up from dried branches, cones, etc.

I liked the variety and volume of plants at the conservatory, it was artfully designed and clearly well-maintained. I look forward to the seasonal updates in the displays and recommend them to others. I do caution, however, that the conservatory is not as large as Allan Gardens.

reviews.title: Great if you are in the neighbourhood
text: I was looking for a place to take my 93 year old dad for a walk in winter, other than a shopping mall. The greenhouses are very nice but quite small. Only worth it if you are in the neighbourhood. Unfortunately we drove quite a distance. Even my Dad said "Is that it?"

To add something to the trip, I asked a local person who told us about Sheridan Nursery which is very close by. That was a nice destination too, beautifully decorated for Christmas. So between the 2, it made an OK free, afternoon with the addition of a stop at a very cute coffee shop on the way home. OK for entertaining an elderly relative that is.

reviews.title: A pleasant surprise
text: I stumbled across this attraction while driving through Toronto (avoiding rush hour traffic). There is an amazing collection of plants separated into garden rooms. The birds and the fish pond are a nice added touch. It is the perfect place to take a break from the city.

reviews.title: Good for a short visit... and it's FREE
text: This is a great place to stop in while in the park. It's a nice tour around if it's rainy or you need a break from the sun. I'm not much of a gardener, so my kids always enjoy checking out the different plants!

reviews.title: Beautiful garden in Toronto
text: This park is beautiful, in the middle of Toronto. It is free, it deserves some time from you, it takes you away from the rushy city and it is really relaxing. It is the biggest hidden sercet in the middle of the city

reviews.title: Tropical paradise in Toronto FREE
text: What a pleasant surprise to see a unique tropical greenhouse attraction for FREE, calm and relaxing. Thanks for the moments here and Angel the parrot was great spirit connection.

reviews.title: It's not a botanical garden
text: For what it is, a part of Centennial Park it's pretty good.
It's a nice space to clear your head in the summer.
If you are looking for somewhere to help pass a  part of a rainy day this might be it.

reviews.title: Lush greenery you can enjoy for free!
text: A few greenhouse "rooms" each filled with different plants - cacti and seasonal. Lovely trees and birds - some wild that somehow entered and a few parrots. Never too crowded and lot's of free parking. A definite pick me up in the long winter months. The seasonal "garden " changes every few weeks. Themed displays for fall, Christmas, Easter. Sometimes flowers for sale. The best part is that it's free! Donations are appreciated and well deserved. Nice playground just next door.

reviews.title: Excellent green house
text: This is a little gem in Etobicoke. Must visit.
They have birds and lot of tropical plants. A good treat to your eyes.
There is a big children's park next to the unit.
It is worth visit on cold weekends.

reviews.title: A little gem to fill the senses
text: We filled in half an hour here on a bitterly cold snowy day. A nice treat to fill the senses with greenery, flowers and fragrance in the dead of winter. A nice place to contemplate for a short while.

reviews.title: Zone of tranquility but I miss the birds
text: This is a favorite spot of mine, especially in the Christmas and Spring Flower show seasons when the weather is cold outside. Beyond the spectacular Christmas displays of poinsettias, flowering cactus and azaleas, or the tulips and daffodils of the Spring, there are year-round tropical plants, cactus and orchids on display. There is a gentle waterfall and pond with Koi fish and turtles. I do miss the birds that they used to have here including a cockatoo named Angel who spoke to passers by as well as smaller cages with budgies and cockatiels. I am not sure why they are no longer part of the greenhouse. Note, on weekend visits especially Saturdays you may run into wedding parties taking photographs in some areas of the greenhouse. Also, in the cactus room it would be wise to keep your children well under control as most of the plants have prickly spines that kids could get into. All in all it is a peaceful, tranquil respite in cold weather seasons when you need a break away to a tropical setting without leaving town.

reviews.title: Good place to visit summer or winter
text: When visiting Centennial Park the greenhouse would be natural you on the list. You will not find it probably in your guide book.  After round of golf or Acres Ski, see some captain or orchids. This is one of few special greenhouses in Toronto area.
If it was not on your bucket list, and you are fan of plants and flowers, add it NOW.
Discover the North West corner of Etobicoke!

reviews.title: 3 greenhouse area - great for 1 hour trip
text: Went here for Mothers Day  to take a few family pictures - it's a small greenhouse with three sections - tall tall ceilings for tropical plants. Many places to take pictures and enjoy a peaceful stroll with family. Small Koi pond and turtles swimming around inside. Plan to spend about 30mins to 1 hour here walking inside the greenhouse and during warm days checking out the small pond and Japanese garden in the front. Free admission - cool trip if you are around the GTA and enjoy greenery.

reviews.title: The Tropics in the Winter
text: To escape the cold dark Canadian winter even for an hour is a real pleasure and this conservatory, filled with flowering plants, tropical trees, orchids, bromeliads, is the place.  A section of the greenhouse is devoted to cactii and succulents, many in flower.  At the other end of the greenhouse were spring bulbs and annual flowers, all blooming two months before their normal bloom times.  At the center of the garden is a pond with large koi and turtles.

reviews.title: Beautiful park with a lot of flowers
text: We have visited this place after landing in Toronto this year. This park is quite large and we had a little nice walk around (about 6 km).
Tip: Make sure you visit the greenhouse, it should be opened during the regular hours.

reviews.title: Cadiallac Park Operation
text: Last time I was at this North Etobicoke park was a number of years to attend a stag which was held at one of the clubhouses. There was over 100 people here and the clubhouse was able to handle this large amount of people inside it. Lot's of parking outside as well.

I was here to check out the walking trails which are well used and maintained for health & safety purposes. I was talking to one person today & they like using the trails. Her local church comes here for picnics. Lot's of room for games and to put out the lawn chairs to relax plus socialize.
One thing that impressed me about the park is that it has both a mini go kart track & skateboard area that is very large. Bet these two areas are popular with the youth in high school.
For years the "garbage hill" is still popular fir downhill skiing and a reasonable price to use.
Park is popular for the locals but you can get here by car or bus transportation if needed.

reviews.title: Beautiful flower setting
text: We live close to the park, we visit the greenhouse regularly. They change the flower setting based on the seasons, we strongly recommend to visit it during Christmas.

reviews.title: Quiet interlude!
text: Great place to spend a little time. I visit this oasis several times a year. For sure during the annual Christmas display. 3 seperate areas - Cactus garden, permanent exibit of tropical flowers and plants and seasonal display area that is replanted several times a year. Great for photographers. Wonderful place on a cold, crisp, Winter's day. The birds, both caged and wild visitors that come and go are fun too

reviews.title: A tropical haven in the winter
text: Actually composed of 3 small greenhouses, the place is very good for a few hours break in the winter - there are even a few exotic birds. There is a small parking just next to the Greenhouse (you should not park at the Centennial Park parking which is a bit far away.

reviews.title: Fairly nice place to visit, especially during the cold winter!
text: It was very warm, as expected of botanical greenhouses. There is no admission fee. There are benches to take a rest or simply to enjoy the view. Location is well-kept and very clean. Plan on returning in the future.

The cactus garden will be quite tempting for children who would want to touch the cacti and they are up front and personal, no barrier installed. So warning to parents: watch your kids closely when you enter the cactus portion of the greenhouse with young children.

reviews.title: Some beautiful place
text: Worth going especially during  colder days. Breeze of tropics in the city. We have a wonderful time every time we visit..

reviews.title: A clemintine tree fruiting here in Winter and free parking!
text: I am sure this is not for everyone, but for those of us who love botanical gardens and greenhouses this was a lovely place to be. We were there for a very pleasant half hour. We were meeting someone at the airport so we were nearby. The parking is free and it is actually fairly easy to get to from the airport. The Christmas display was lovely. Happy New Year!

reviews.title: Greenhouse
text: Went to see blossoming flowers but mainly cactae no colour.  Special holidays will have the colour--otherwise not exciting and needs to be expanded to a very large degree to make the trip worthwhile if you're coming from out-of-town.

reviews.title: Nice place to go spend time in the winter
text: It is a nice place to visit in the winter. See some green, it is free and there are seasonal plant displays.

reviews.title: Beautiful!
text: Visited with a family during Mother's Day. Beautiful flowers and plants, the landscapers did great job arranging plants, stones, mini ponds (cool fish is swimming in there)  and waterfalls. LOTS of benches where people could  take a rest and enjoy the tranquility of the greenhouse. Very knowledgeable gentleman at the entrance will tell you about the place and plants. The flowers change 6 times a year so there is always something new to see. We had an enjoyable morning. Recommended for families and nature lovers.

reviews.title: Beautiful location
text: Hi everyone.  Visited here on Sunday - have been coming here since the 1980's!  Beautiful location - lots of flowers, cactus, bridge, waterfall, etc. Hot and humid feels wonderful with the Winter we had and Spring we're having still feeling like Winter!  If you're craving warmth along with beautiful, bright and colourful, smells wonderful, etc this is the place for you.  Also, free parking and free admission.  How great is that!  :D  On Sunday they were playing opera music which was really relaxing and certainly matched the environment.  Wonderful location for photography!

reviews.title: Beautiful piece of paradise
text: Beautiful place to visit for those who loves  and enjoys flowers. The people here do great job - so please feel free to say big " Thank you"  and do not forget to donate some bucks since this place is free to visit.
During each season you can enjoy different flower's exhibitions themes. And all of them are Gorgeous!!!!
Definitely place to relax and listen to classic music and birds songs.

reviews.title: Lovely conservatory
text: Centennial Park is one of the biggest Park in Toronto. The conservatory is a place of lovely tranquility. It's free to visit and there's a donation box if you wish to contribute to their upkeep of variety of exotic plants and flowers.
If you are in the area and have an hour spare, definitely drop in and take in the experience.

reviews.title: First Time Not Last Time
text: Lived in Etobicoke most of my life and 10 minutes from home and had not visited. A new camera, macro lens and needed practice meant a visit. Quiet, well maintained bright and calming. Admission is free open all year round from 10 AM. I have to go back 2 hours not long enough. Parking close by grounds in park worth a visit. Some people take picnic lunches and spend the day enjoying whole area.

reviews.title: Absolutely stunning
text: Breathtaking to see so much greenery. Well laid out, alot seemed to b from my country. Smoke trees and allium gigantium  would b a cool addition if possible.
